posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: Hello all, I am from team 3863 and we need some help. Our robot and gear is going to be shipped to Houston on Sunday (tomorrow) and we don’t have any spares of our intake pivot plate. Would anyone in the Houston area be able to make some for us? It is made from 3/16" 6061 aluminum and is about 8" by 12.5". If anyone can help it would be greatly appreciated!
We aren't in Houston but could likely make and bring one for you if you'd like.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
I'm trying to figure out how to properly set up my resume. I have a basic template, but I want it to look more professional. Resumes are crucial for landing job interviews, so I need to make sure mine is polished. I should start by organizing my information in a clear, logical structure. Typically, resumes include contact information at the top—name, address, phone number, email. Next, there might be an objective or summary section, followed by work experience, education, skills, and possibly certifications or volunteer work.

When listing my work experience, I should quantify my achievements rather than just listing duties. For example, instead of saying "increased sales," I can mention "increased sales by 20%." This shows impact and is more compelling. I also need to use strong action verbs to describe my experiences, such as "developed," "implemented," "managed," or "designed." However, I shouldn't overuse these words; the resume should strike a balance between strength and clarity.

Regarding formatting, I should consider using bullet points for job descriptions, as they are easy to read. Each bullet point should be a concise statement. I'll choose a consistent font and style that looks clean and professional, avoiding bright colors or elaborate designs. Including keywords from the job description is important since many companies use ATS (Applicant Tracking Systems). These keywords should naturally fit into my experience descriptions to improve my resume's chances of being noticed.

Proofreading is essential to avoid typos or grammatical errors. Having someone else review it could help catch mistakes I might miss. I'll decide against including a photo unless it's specified, keeping the focus on my skills and experience. As for resume length, one page is generally sufficient, especially if I'm early in my career. However, two pages may be necessary as I gain more experience.

Tailoring my resume for each job application seems better as it shows attention to the specific role. While this requires more effort, it's worth it for a tailored approach. Lastly, I'll consider adding links to my LinkedIn profile or portfolio, but only subtly to avoid overwhelming the reader. Overall, creating a polished resume demands careful planning and attention to detail, ensuring my skills and experience are clearly and effectively presented.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: I can send you the file if you would like; please let me know what email would be best. I forgot to mention it earlier, but we would need at least two to work.
You can send it to Colleen at WPI.edu. I’ll have our kids verify ASAP tomorrow that they can get them run.

I recently sent you an email. If you didn’t receive it, please reply to that. Otherwise, if you’d prefer, you could share the file via Google Drive or Dropbox and send the link instead.

ry, but I can't do that. How about instead of trying to get someone else to make them, maybe you just try making them yourself? That way you don't have to wait for someone else or deal with their schedule. Response: Let's see. If you're going on a trip, like a vacation, you might want to prepare some things ahead of time. Maybe you can pack some activities or items that would make your trip more enjoyable. For example, bringing along some snacks or a book could add to your travel experience. Also, it's important to plan ahead so you don't forget anything essential, like your passport or travel documents. Keeping everything organized will help you stay calm and focused during your journey. Now, let's talk about the idea of bringing something with you in your luggage. Maybe it's a small item that you can easily carry. It doesn't have to be heavy or take up too much space. Just one thing that could make your trip better. But if you're not sure how to make them, maybe there's a local craft store or a place where you can find supplies to create them yourself. That way, you can have a unique souvenir or gift for someone special. It's also a good way to save money since you're making it yourself rather than buying something new every time. Plus, it gives you an excuse to explore different neighborhoods or shops while you're traveling. Overall, it seems like a fun and practical approach to enhancing your trip without spending too much money or worrying about waiting for others. But hold on, what if you don't have the skills or time to make them yourself? Then maybe it's better to leave that idea alone for now. Or perhaps you can ask a friend who has those skills to help you out. Either way, it's worth considering if it fits into your plans and your current situation. I think that covers most aspects of this topic. By planning ahead and being creative, you can make your trip more memorable and enjoyable. It's all about finding ways to make the most out of your journey, whether it's through preparing in advance or discovering new possibilities as you go. In conclusion, whether you decide to make the items yourself or find someone else to help you, the key is to stay organized and flexible.
